text: This will be the NASA Space Story number 1076, 4 minutes 30 seconds coming in 3, 2, 1. This is the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration. solar maximum mission satellite which was retrieved and repaired in orbit during a recent space shuttle mission Solar Max's seven scientific instruments are constantly looking at the sun in search of clues that will help scientists understand solar flares and other solar phenomena. Project scientist for Solar Maximum Mission is Dr. Bruce Woodgate. Solar flares. These are very large explosions on the sun which occur in magnetic loops. They're a magnetic structure sticking up out of the sun, usually forming closed loops in active regions on the sun, around sunspots. Also, there are open field regions which are called coronal holes and these are the origin of the solar wind, which streams out into the Earth's environment and hits the Earth and cause magnetic storms when they switch over from one magnetic polarity to another. Solar Max gathered a wealth of information until it lost its ability to point with fine precision at the Sun. The successful Solar Maximum Repair Mission last April not only demonstrated the shuttle's capability to service satellites in space, but it also revived the most ambitious and successful solar flare research ever attempted. Shortly after its repair, SolarMax detected the largest solar flares seen by any instrument. Right after the repair we did see extreme activity. The primary mission is still to find out the physics of flares and see if we can find out anything about their predictability, about the buildup to when a flare would occur, what their triggering mechanisms are. Scientists also want to understand more about the relationship between the sun and the earth. As both flares and active prominences erupt out of the sun, they give rise to mass ejections from the corona. Pieces of the corona blast off and go into the solar wind, and they travel along magnetic field lines, through the solar wind, and some of them will hit the earth and give rise to large magnetic storms. These disturbances can trigger dramatic environmental effects. Auroras streak the skies in the northern latitudes. Radio communications are garbled. Surges in power lines can cut off electricity and darken entire cities. And orbiting spacecraft and astronauts are endangered. Scientists would like to know more about solar flares in order to forecast when and how unusual solar activity will affect the Earth's environment. Another area they're trying to understand is the solar cycle itself. We want to look at the total solar flux, which appears to have been declining something like a tenth of a percent over the last four years from 1980 to 1984. If this decline were to occur and continue over many decades, it would eventually affect the climate on Earth. Another area of research is cometary physics. We intend to observe Comet Halley in early 1986. For about two months, as the comet gets nearest to the Sun, where it's most active and most interesting and brightest, it gets so close to the Sun that it can't be observed by telescopes from the ground or by other instruments from satellites, such as the International Ultraviolet Explorer because it can't look closer than 45 degrees to the Sun without burning itself out. But we intend to go off every third orbit for about two months. So we'll have an observation about every four or five hours of the comet and go off and observe it, particularly with the coronagraph instrument and see the structure of the tail. So that's interesting both for cometary physics and for the effects on the solar wind, or the effects of the solar wind upon the comet. This has been The Space Story, A weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This will be the NASA Space Story, number 1077. Four minutes, thirty seconds. Coming in three, two, one. This is The Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station, and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. In January of this year, President Reagan directed NASA to begin the development of a space station, setting a new goal in space for America. The space station will weigh approximately 40 tons, house six to eight men and women for up to six months at a time, and offer living quarters somewhat larger than a one-bedroom apartment. The station will come equipped with scientific and industrial laboratories, a satellite repair shop, a telescope platform for observing the sky, and another platform for looking back at Earth. It will also have a half acre of solar cells furnishing 75 kilowatts of electric power. Dr. Robert Jastrow, former director of NASA's Goddard Institute for Space Studies and now a professor at Dartmouth, believes that once the space station is in place, science gets a free ride on it. The most important scientific projects that NASA has ever orbited, in my opinion, are the astronomical observatories. There are four of them, four great observatories. The Space Telescope, the advanced x-ray observatory, Axaf, the gamma-ray observatory, and the advanced infrared observatory. And they're going up between about 1986 and the year 2000. Possibly the most interesting projects in science in this century because they can reveal, give us information about how the universe came into being, they can see out to the edge of space back into the beginning of time. With the space station, you can repair and refurbish these instruments in orbit. You can extend their lifetime to many decades by taking out the instruments of the vintage of 1980 or 1990 and installing new instruments at the focal point of the telescope with electronics and devices that we don't even dream about now but that will exist in the year 2000. We asked Dr. Jastrow to explain how these observatories will open new windows to the universe. the space telescope can see twice as far as telescopes on the ground even larger ones because the turbulence of the earth's atmosphere does not blur its vision and it makes sharper images and therefore can see a fainter objects farther away if we can see out to the edge view of the universe because light travels at a finite speed that's the same as seeing back to the moment of creation the so-called big bang the gamma ray observatory will tell us something about gamma rays such as those produced by the annihilation of matter and antimatter. It'll be an insight which will point us in some whole new direction towards perceiving the mysteries of the cosmos. The infrared observatory will reveal hidden objects in space dark objects. It will tell us how stars and planets form." A space station could also serve as a staging area for assembling planetary missions. Alistair B. B. There are certain flights to the planets of tremendous general interest which are too expensive to be done on a one-shot approach by direct descent from the ground. I have in mind especially setting up a base on the moon for scientific observations and then carrying out an unmanned flight to Mars with the return of a surface sample. The second mission will shed light on the question of Martian life, which was never satisfactorily resolved by Viking. There is another application of the station that has commercial value and may also have great humanitarian importance. And that relates to the possibility of manufacturing life-saving medicines in space with yields of 400 to 800 times the yields you can get on the ground. Now, what a great return that is to the taxpayer and to the well-being of our society out of this new development in the NASA program. This has been the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This will be NASA Space Story number 1078, 4 minutes 30 seconds, coming in 3. Two, one. This is the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. 10. We have a go for main engine start. 7, 6, 5. We have main engine start. We have a cutoff. NTT, we have an SSR support. We have an abort by the onboard computers of the Orbiter Discovery. Last June, an onboard computer on the space shuttle Discovery detected a valve failure and ordered a shutdown of the craft's main engines just a few seconds before liftoff. It was the first launch abort in the 12-mission history of the shuttle program and the second such abort in the 23 years of American manned space flight. The first occurred during the Gemini 6 mission in 1965. Jesse Moore is the acting Shuttle director at NASA Headquarters in Washington, DC. Jesse Moore, General Shuttle Director System We had a problem with one of the valves in engine number three. The system immediately switched from channel A to the redundant channel B and started the operation. The general purpose computer at that time, sensed that we didn't have full redundancy on each of the engines. So it started a shutdown sequence. That's the way the system was designed. That's the way it's tested during the test programs. And our software system then begins an orderly shutdown of the engines. And at the time the shutdown sequence occurs, we inhibit the ignition command to the solid rocket boosters so the shuttle doesn't lift off. The faulty engine has been removed from Discovery and has gone through rigorous testing at NASA's National Space Technology Laboratories in Mississippi. We feel very confident that we will be able to identify the problem that we had on the launch pad and that we have since put a new engine back into Discovery. And the engines we have on Discovery now are the original engines that we had on board at the time we did a flight readiness firing back in the May time frame prior to our attempted launch in June. So we feel very confident that the engines will work fine on this particular upcoming launch of Discovery. NASA is planning to combine the cargo from what was to be the June flight, or 41D, and a second flight, originally slated for August 29th. The payloads and discoveries flight now include the solar array, designed to study the possibilities of obtaining electrical power from the Sun for future satellites, and the electrophoresis experiment, a 700-pound box designed by McDonnell-Douglas Corporation to manufacture drug components in orbit for medical purposes. Both of these experiments were originally scheduled for Discovery's first flight. The astronauts will also deploy several communications satellites. The crew on Discovery's maiden flight will remain the same as was assigned to the 41D June mission. Later on this year, in another space shuttle mission, NASA may attempt to rescue two satellites which were lost in space last February. We are optimistic about being officially requested to go and retrieve those two satellites, although we still do not have a formal request from either the Indonesians or Western Union or the underwriters which represented the insurance companies which insured those two particular launches. In the rescue, NASA would command the satellites to fire their small engines, lowering their orbits so that Challenger could reach them. If that worked, the satellites would be ordered to slow their spin rate to about one revolution per minute. an astronaut wearing the jet powered manned maneuvering unit could move from Challenger to rendezvous with the satellites. I think the future potential of the shuttle is virtually unlimited. For many year's the possibility of flying into space was limited to trained astronauts. In the near future NASA will be looking into the possibility of flying ordinary citizens into space journalists, poets, writers, scientists, engineers or anyone with a particular experiment or job to do in space. This has been the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This will be NASA's Space Story number 1079, 4 minutes, 30 seconds. Coming in 3, 2, 1. This is the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Back in 1980, a small California company was contracted by NASA to develop a new type of safety net for use on the space shuttle. The net had to be fire-resistant and also strong. Nomex was the only flame-retardant material available that would do the job, but it was not very strong. The nets had to withstand an impact of 3,500 pounds. Bill Kirkland, president of West Coast Netting, continues this story. Those design criterias that we were faced with were very, very stringent because of the low tenacity fiber that we had. The fiber being down in strength, 70% from nylon, 65% from polyester, was the real problem is how to get the net to work and to withstand the loads. In the process of doing this, we have arrived with a new type of twisting for making twines, which under load will break evenly, as opposed to one of the three ends failing by themselves, which has been what has been done in the past. By doing it this way, we have gained tensile strength of somewhere around 10%. We have tied that manufacturing process to the fishing industry, and along with that have a new product called Hyperester, which is a high-density, high-specific gravity in the polyester family fiber, and this product is designed to compete with what the Japanese or the average tuna net has been built out of for the last 25 years. The Japanese net is composed of a tubular design material which must fill with water in order to sink. So consequently, it's not as efficient a tool as it could be. The product that we have designed is a twisted product which has no voids in the middle of it. It's a high specific gravity product which means it weighs 2.7 times more than nylon in the water and loses no tensile strength when it's wet. Production has been increased from 17 tons on an average per set to 55 tons, on an average, per set, this type of production is definitely significant. We have also had sets that have run up over four, five, up to 700 tons. With the product we've got to learn how to fish all over again because of the production being so great. Because the American fishing industry has been facing rising costs in equipment and fuel, it's been difficult to compete against foreign fishing fleets. The vessels are becoming more and more expensive. They're up into the 10 million dollar range, and burning fuel, a million dollars worth of fuel a year. So we feel like this is definitely a significant gain. There's not too many times that you come along and you can develop a product for an industry and show a gain factor of 20, 30 percent. We feel like that's a rather conservative figure. Our production has continued to show us that we were averaging somewhere around three times more production than what the current net is being used. What that means to the fishermen is that an 80-day trip is reduced down to 29 days. The 29 days versus the 80 days at 5,000 gallons of fuel a day, just the fuel savings alone becomes monumental. Fishing Nets, a new space age spin-off with down-to-earth, down-to-the-sea applications. This has been the Space Story, a weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by this station and NASA, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This will be the NASA Space Story number 1076. 4 minutes 30 seconds. Coming in 3, 2, 1. This is The Space Story, A weekly space and aeronautics report brought to you by...
